message.content:
cs.CV, cs.LG, cs.NE, cs.AI, cs.CL 

This paper is likely to belong to the computer vision (cs.CV) sub-category as it deals with perceptual similarity judgment based on re-training a deep convolution neural network (DCNN) to capture the notion of object persistence and continuity in our visual experience. It also involves distance metric learning and view-manifold modification, which are common topics in computer vision research. 

The paper also involves machine learning (cs.LG) as it discusses the re-training process of the DCNN and the transfer of learning to novel objects. 

Neural networks (cs.NE) is another likely sub-category as the paper deals with the modification of feature representation in deep networks and the development of perceptual similarity judgment in biological neural networks. 

Artificial intelligence (cs.AI) is also a possible sub-category as the paper involves the development of a model for similarity perception of objects. 

Finally, natural language processing (cs.CL) is a less likely sub-category as the paper does not involve any language processing, but it does discuss the matching of human perceptual similarity judgment, which could be relevant to natural language understanding.
